resources.string:
"Consider the following two part statement: "
 
"If you get an A, then I will give you a dollar."
 
"In the corresponding truth table (if P then Q) the P (antecedent) represents the first part, "If you get an A". The Q (consequent) represents the second part, "then I will give you a dollar". 
"The entire statement will only be true if I keep my promise and false if I don't." 
"Suppose you get an A and I give you a dollar. Since I kept my promise, the implication is it's true. This corresponds to the first line in the table." 
"Suppose you get an A but I don't give you a dollar. Since I didn't keep my promise, the implication is false. This corresponds to the second line in the table." 
"What if you don't get an A? Whether or not I give you a dollar, I haven't broken my promise. Thus, the implication can\â€™t be false, so it must be true. This explains the last two lines of the table."
image of a conditional if P then Q truth table

Given the length of each side of the triangle (SSS), enter three side lengths to create a similar triangle
Given the length of two sides and an angle between them (SAS), enter a new SAS to create a similar triangle
Given the lengths of sides A and B, enter the length of side C rounded to two decimal places
